node.title: After a School Shooting, Should Parents Be Prosecuted?
node.description: A Michigan prosecutor hopes the strategy can prevent more school shootings. But some on both sides of the gun control debate are wary.
node.content: ["This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.", "On Nov. 30, a 15-year-old boy wandering the halls of Oxford High School in Michigan with a semiautomatic pistol opened fire, killing four children and grievously wounding several others. There was much about this particular school shooting, the deadliest in the United States in three years, that seemed tragically familiar: The shooter was a student at the school, and male; he had shown signs of being on the brink of violence; and he had used a gun that belonged, legally, to his parents.", "Which is also why it came as a surprise when the prosecutor in the case, Karen McDonald, announced the highly unusual decision to file criminal charges against the parents, not just the child, who she will argue committed involuntary manslaughter by allowing their son access to a gun while ignoring signs of violent thoughts.", "McDonald has called her strategy \u201ca brand-new way of approaching school shootings,\u201d one that she hopes will have a preventive effect. Many gun control proponents agree. But can this approach deliver on its promises, is it fair, and what drawbacks and risks does it pose? Here\u2019s what people are saying.", "It is not unheard-of for adults to be charged with child abuse, violation of gun laws or even involuntary manslaughter after children too young to be prosecuted accidentally shoot themselves or other children. But for the most part, adult prosecution for school shootings by children is rare:", "\u201cI can\u2019t think of a high-profile mass shooting where the parents were prosecuted,\u201d said Allison Anderman, director of local policy at the Giffords Law Center to Prevent Gun Violence.", "Why? Legal experts told The Times that a major hurdle to prosecution is the absence in most states \u2014 including Michigan \u2014 of what\u2019s known as child-access prevention, or C.A.P., laws, which require gun owners to secure their weapons when children are in the household. McDonald has tried to get around that hurdle by charging the parents with involuntary manslaughter.", "But the burden of proof for such a charge is high: The jury will have to be convinced that the parents, James and Jennifer Crumbley, were \u201caware not just generally that their son was troubled but aware that he would or could do this \u2014 shoot up that school,\u201d said Eve Brensike Primus, a professor at the University of Michigan School of Law. \u201cThat requires a level of mental culpability that is more challenging for a prosecutor to prove.\u201d", "McDonald says the timeline is damning for the Crumbleys:", "Many gun control proponents and commentators see promise in McDonald\u2019s approach. \u201cMaybe heightened parental responsibility standards is a solution that both sides of the gun debate can get behind,\u201d writes Danny Cevallos, a legal analyst for MSNBC. \u201cWe can provide schools with security plans and active shooter drills, but making more parents criminally responsible could be a powerful preventative fix.\u201d", "Others, though, are skeptical. The defense lawyers representing the couple, who have pleaded not guilty, have said that a fuller picture that absolves the parents will emerge. McDonald herself has acknowledged her strategy faces long odds. And even if it succeeds, it could well end up an exception that proves the rule. \u201cI don\u2019t think this is going to spark some wave of charges against parents,\u201d Primus said. \u201cIt\u2019s not an easy charge to make.\u201d", "The notion of prosecuting parents of school shooters, in this case and more generally, has critics on both sides of the gun control debate. In National Review, Andrew McCarthy argues McDonald is inappropriately trying to compensate for Michigan\u2019s lack of child-access prevention laws by, in effect, retroactively criminalizing the Crumbleys\u2019 behavior and calling it manslaughter.", "\u201cIt is one thing to say that the parents were egregiously derelict \u2014 just as, for example, store owners are egregiously derelict when they sell to suspicious characters substances (including explosive powders) that can be used to make bombs,\u201d he writes. \u201cBut that does not make the parents\u2019 conduct a criminal violation, much less make them responsible for homicide \u2014 a much more serious crime, even in the form of involuntary manslaughter, than the C.A.P. crime that Michigan has refused to codify.\u201d", "Some gun control proponents on the left also doubt that putting the Crumbleys in jail would have much of a deterrent effect on future school shootings. What it would do, Kevin Freed argues at The World Socialist Web Site, is establish a dangerous precedent for prosecutorial overreach.", "\u201cChildren will be jailed for criminal threats without due process, many will be unfairly expelled, and the social ills that produce so many broken people will persist, paving the way for the next horror story,\u201d he writes. Instead of taking on \u201cthe fascistic gun lobby,\u201d he adds, \u201cthe capitalist state proposes, as it always does, that the solution lies in putting more people in prison, bringing in more police, expanding the powers of prosecutors.\u201d", "And who should we expect to bear the brunt of the state\u2019s expanded punitive power? Evan Bernick, an assistant professor of law at the Northern Illinois University College of Law, predicts it would be Black parents.", "\u201cGiven common negative stereotypes about Black criminality and parental irresponsibility, holding parents responsible for their children\u2019s felonies could easily lead to still more racially disparate prosecutions,\u201d he writes in The Washington Post. And because racial minorities are also more at risk for gang involvement, \u201cprosecutors might target Black parents who fail to identify warning signs in advance and don\u2019t intervene before someone gets hurt or killed.\u201d", "Even those who support the decision to charge the Crumbleys agree that other measures are needed to prevent school shootings. One option is more behavioral surveillance. James Densley and Jillian Peterson, professors of criminal justice, propose \u201ca nationally funded mandate that would create multiagency threat assessment and crisis response teams in every school and community so that children in crisis feel seen and heard, and can be immediately connected to the help and support they need.\u201d", "But there are limits to this kind of intervention. As Jessica Grose notes in The Times, there is no single reliable profile for a school shooter. Administrators are sometimes wary of contacting law enforcement, and parents aren\u2019t always willing to cooperate, as the Crumbleys showed. And even in retrospect, experts don\u2019t agree about whether administrators at Oxford High School should have known that there was a credible threat to other students.", "\u201cI confess that after reporting this out, I don\u2019t feel optimistic,\u201d Grose writes. Teachers and school counselors \u201caren\u2019t psychic, and in a country where there are, according to one study, 120.5 firearms for every 100 residents, there will always be the potential for a worst-case scenario.\u201d", "But for children, at least, C.A.P. laws may provide a politically viable way to reduce the availability of guns. Research suggests that such laws lead to a substantial reduction in both gun-carrying among high school students and unintentional firearm injuries and child deaths. Unlike McDonald\u2019s strategy of implicating the Crumbleys in their child\u2019s crime, C.A.P. laws are narrowly tailored, which may make them less likely to be used for racially targeted prosecution, Bernick says. And according to a 2018 survey, such laws are supported by nearly 60 percent of Americans who own guns and nearly 80 percent of those who don\u2019t.", "\u201cThe simple truth is if students didn\u2019t have easy access to guns, there would be few, if any, school shootings in America,\u201d Shannon Watts, the founder of Moms Demand Action for Gun Sense in America, writes. \u201cThese laws should be nonpartisan, noncontroversial and nonpolitical, and states should implement them immediately so that reckless gun owners can be held accountable for their negligence.\u201d", "Do you have a point of view we missed? Email us at debatable@nytimes.com. Please note your name, age and location in your response, which may be included in the next newsletter.", "\u201cChild Access Laws Are Increasingly Proven to Protect Kids from Guns\u201d [The Trace]", "\u201cWhen parents enable gun massacres, they should be locked up, too\u201d [The Washington Post]", "\u201cMore states consider laws to punish parents if children fire unsecured guns\u201d [The Washington Post]", "\u201cThe Oxford Mass Shooting Shows the Limits of \u2018Hardening\u2019 Schools\u201d [The Trace]", "\u201cProsecuting Ethan Crumbley\u2019s parents over the Oxford school shooting is an admission of failure\u201d [Yahoo]"]
